commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Two-cent pieces?  (2)-(3)
2. Material for a certain pocket  (4)
3. Liner notes?  (3)(6)
4. Command that initiates a chase  (2)(5)
5. Exclamation often made while covering the face  (5)


OP-EDS
PITA
SEA SHANTY
GO FETCH
ACHOO

"It‚Äôs SARGE, with an A, even though the full word is ‚Äúsergeant.‚Äù

Because SERGE is a fabric.
Bright and breezy puzzle with a cute theme. 44A was a fun variation.
I FEVER: [makes people camp outside the Apple store?]
I feel meh about "mid"
I have to say that a SPHERE is not a solid. A ball is the solid you were thinking of. A sphere is the shell of a ball.

FIGURE EIGHT totally reminded me of the Schoolhouse Rock videos ü•∞ https://youtu.be/UCGNUo-XQJ8?feature=shared I wish they still made learning videos like this for kids today. I still find myself reciting things from Schoolhouse Rock songs ü§£ Thank you for this fun trip down memory lane, Rena!!

I'm sure we're going to be roasted for 29D.

Again.
Fun Monday after a weird Sunday

‚ÄúMariana trench, still waters, the meaning of life, Death Valley, Chicago pizza, Lake Baikal.‚Äù

After their escapades with my Shakespeare, I hope the emus don‚Äôt DEEP SIX this one.

Cirrus, cirrocumulus, cirrostratus, altocumulus, altostratus, nimbostratus, cumulus, stratocumulus, stratus.


CLOUD NINE
This was so much fun! A great Monday. Loved the theme. Thanks, Rena!! Y‚Äôall have a great Monday!
What a great way to begin a Monday! Everyone have a wonderful week!
Very cool.  The rare monday I went very slow as I was enjoying it so much.

"So-so, in modern slang" was not MEH üòï.

It's "OK", or whatever the kids are calling it these days. Fun puzzle all the same.

Everything that I would ask for from a Monday. Fun amusing theme; and I always enjoy when I get the first theme answer and can try and guess the rest. Excellent fill, easy enough for a Monday but not a lot of glue, and enough nonobvious ones that I have to stretch just a bit. Last I just want to say‚Äîif there isn‚Äôt a Great BISON National Park,  there should be. I would go there.
60A was pretty tasteless in several ways.
Absolutely love the theme here. Hope that they have puzzles with themes everyday of the week

When I read the clue for the first themer, I thought we'd be dealing with an [ahem] I.Q. Test...
That was my lol moment in solving this puzzle, so thank you for that, Rena.

Thank you as well for such a smart and creative theme, enhanced by the very nice fill. 
Well done!
Love the early week themed puzzles, keep them coming!

I don't think I've ever made such a hash of a corner of a Monday puzzle as I did in SE corner today. In my defense I was kind of dozing off while trying to complete it. However, I know exactly where the photo atop Sam's column was taken. It's on Hicks Street in Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn. The store was originally called F Line Bagels, but the MTA went after them for trademark infringement, so the proprietor/s? just stuck that bagel over the F line symbol and changed the name. https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/24/nyregion/c-train-cafe-the-mta-may-put-up-a-fight.html?unlocked_article_code=1.108.Mtn3.einMMSvTFXBH&smid=url-share
Technically Bumble Bees sting but come on - the panda of the bee kingdom is too lovable to sting.

Despite my quibbles with BUMBLEBEE, today's puzzle wasn't MID.  Do us a SOLID and keep it up with the themed Mondays, please!

Snatch, lift, swipe, nick, pinch - TAKEFIVE?

And kudos to anyone who can give us FORTYWINKS.

DEF not MID. 

A banger!

I'm skeptical of that DEF/IFEVER crossing.
Is "suresies" even a thing?
I enjoyed this puzzle but I‚Äôm side-eyeing the clue for ‚Äúif ever‚Äù

Today my NYTXW streak reached 3,650. Not exactly a celestial decade ‚Äî leap years would like a word ‚Äî but close enough for a milestone.

Ten years of quiet mornings, clever misdirections, tiny triumphs, daily digital gold stars, and the ritual of filling a blank grid only to do it all over again the next day.

My deepest thanks to Will and his amazing editorial team, the hundreds of constructors, and the oft-unsung tech team that keeps the app from exploding whenever a constructor decides the grid should resemble a flamingo performing modern dance.

Crosswords are a daily reminder that persistence pays off. Onward to 3,651!

I seem to remember I didn't much like previous grids of Rena Cohen, because of an overreliance on trivia. Today however was quite enjoyable, with a theme like a baby Thursday, and generally pleasurably Monday-easy fill. Not bad at all.
When I fixed 48A InEVER ("I never ..."), 43D suddenly made sense.
Fantastic Monday puzzle. As someone else commented, I also disregarded my timer so I could enjoy the ride.
Great fun, thank you Rena!

Cake, work, advice, information, the action, my mind, jewelry, paper : Pieces of Eight

Bulls, Bears, Cubs, Board of Trade, Tribune, White Sox, Deep Dish Pizza : Chicago 7
This one went v well for me! Fun puzzle.

Solomon?

JUST ONE 

(Loved today‚Äôs puzzle, loving the comments, couldn‚Äôt resist joining, but too lazy to count above 1, and ‚ÄúABSOLUTE ZERO‚Äù was hard to clue - maybe ‚Äúlack of vodka‚Äù?)

IMHO this was DEF the most fun Monday puzzle, column, and comment section since I started solving in 2020.

what a delightful puzzle! i had a great time solving this while sipping my coffee this morning. such a fun and creative theme, easily one of my favorite mondays.

DAILY DOZEN.
I had ‚ÄúI Never‚Äù  so this ended up being longer for me. More coffee needed.
A bit steep for Monday, but that's good, I think. A good learning experience for the newcomers.

Oh, it‚Äôs a terrific theme, with SOLID interesting answers, not to mention the fun kind of answers that make you want to come up with more.  What a hoot!

Add a well-scrubbed answer set that includes symmetrical fauna cuteness (BUMBLEBEE, GROUNDHOG), and the lovely PuzzPair¬© of STRIP/NUDE.

Oh, and SKEEBALL triggered the marvelous specific childhood memory of how amazing it felt to get the ball into the little middle circle.  That feeling never lessened.  Hadn‚Äôt thought about that in forever, and I remember that feeling exactly.

I remember also, with a smile, Rena‚Äôs last puzzle, which featured, of all things, the varieties of pretzels.  That puzzle was feel-good, and so was this.  

What a terrific way to start the day.  Thank you, Rena!

Interesting that today's puzzle involved numbers. Because I solved the puzzle in 7:12, but it has been recorded as 2:24 - my best time - which would never have happened : ).

The title of today's Wordplay column, together with its wonderful photograph, reminds me of the joke:

A Buddhist monk walks up to a hot dog stand and says, "Make me one with everything."
Very nice, O KING. DOUBLE OS, EVEN was delightful.

That really was an amazing Monday puzzle! Sometimes I'm not all that jazzed for the Monday morning sprint through the puzzle, but this one had the entertaining theme and a few clues that required a bit of extra thought. Wonderful!

I'll join the chorus (daddy sings bass): Really clever theme and a very enjoyable workout. Today's puzzle find was inspired by 35d. A Thursday from February 2 (!) 1995 by Bob and Sharon Klahn. Some theme answers were GROUNDHOG and SIXWEEK. And it was a 15 x 15 puzzle, but there was one 16 letter answer down the very middle of the puzzle with the first square protruding above the top. And that was... PUNXSUTAWNEYPHIL Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/2/1995&g=1&d=D ...

Otherwise, a real delight!

A-freaking-mazing Monday, Rena, Freyya bless you!

Well, darn!  I printed the puzzle, and on my way from the kitchen (yes, that's where my desk is, and I also have a sewing machine and an ironing board permanently installed--who needs a 'breakfast area' when the dining room is just a few steps away?)...anyhow, I looked down and saw Ketanji and Stonewall, and got 60A instantly, identifying the clever theme and more or less ruining the fun of an unfolding Aha! Moment.

Quiblet:
Most BUMBLEBEE varieties are peaceable and do not sting; why not clue as  "Insect that pollinates"??

Lovely puzzle; thanks, Rena Cohen!
I thought bumblebees didn't sting, but after doing a bit of research, found that I was wrong. The thing one learns from crosswords!
Wow....what a great Monday! A solid 10!

Can't remember the last time I had so much fun with a puzzle. The theme was giggle-icious and the fill was quite Monday-ish. NSC was my only stumble. Okay, now I know, and next time it won't be my stumble. Live and acquire knowledge.

Recently one of my grands told me she had to learn Latin in school and was fuming at a language she thought she would never ever need. I delighted in highlighting the many ways it would come in handy: It will be so much easier for you to pick up French, Italian, Spanish, all the romance languages based on Latin. You will be able to understand your Prescriptions. And most importantly, you will be a whiz at crosswords! 

She is too polite to tell me what she thought of my justifications.

What a fun puzzle. The theme clues had me stumped for a bit, until the words with "--OO--" in them. Then it was, "Wait a minute... " and the light dawned.

A perfect Monday puzzle -- doable, but not ridiculously easy. And yes, I did giggle. These puzzles are a lovely antidote to what's going on in the world. Thanks to the constructor!
That was fun!! What a way to start the week (excluding Sunday)! I'm feeling I can accomplish all kinds of things. Thank you.
Fun,cheerful puzzle. Perfect for a chilly Monday morning.

For crossword reasons I‚Äôm always grateful that Monday comes after Saturday and Sunday :) especially after yesterday‚Äôs puzzle gave me a run for my money. And today‚Äôs puzzle was fun and light and gave me several moments of wordplay-induced delight. (My favorite was JACKSON FIVE.)
Clever theme, I think this was a wonderful Monday.
If you want to see Dot used as a name, can‚Äôt do better than ‚ÄúJulie and Julia.‚Äù

Man, I came here to argue that bumblebees can't sting, and instead learned they can.

Gonna be an awesome week!
Took a minute to get the theme, which was a good thing. Solid Monday puzzle that still gave my brain a bit of exercise. Three cheers to the constructors (or should I say "rah, prost, and sant√©"?)!
I don't usually comment on Monday puzzles but I really enjoyed this theme
So cute!  I‚Äôm dying ü•∞

Okay, so how Peggy is from Margaret is because waaaaay back in the day a fun thing to do was switch the M for a P.  So you go from Margaret to Maggie to Peggy. Kind of how Polly is a nickname for Mary bc Mary to Molly to Polly.
Dorothy to Dot is pretty simple: Dorothy to Dotty to Dot.
Lol i got stuck in the NE corner for a sec. I had Meh, ASeA, and I‚Äôm not good at sports, but figured it couldn‚Äôt be REhS

Fun puzzle. While I enjoyed all of the theme entries the 007 one was my favorite and also the one I found most challenging. Thanks Rena Cohen for this enjoyable puzzle. 

Re bumblebees‚Ä¶in our previous home we had a slightly raised bed with several Catmint plants which produced many little purple flowers. The bees loved them! At times there‚Äôd be a dozen or more flying from flower to flower. While working on other parts of the bed I eventually became accustomed to their presence so much so that when one of them happened to land on my hand or arm I developed the habit of petting their ‚Äúfurry‚Äù little backs. From this behavior I received two reactions; either they sat and let me pet them for a brief moment or they flew away on first contact. Never once was I stung.
Proof that a puzzle doesn't need to vbe tricky to be fun. thank you, Ms. Cohen! Here's Barbra's take on 11D: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e41IyhJVCJ8&list=RDe41IyhJVCJ8&start_radio=1

Presidential term X 2

EIGHT IS ENOUGH

Okay, I'm going to bring up the nittiest of nits, just because, the last time this came up, I found the situation so interesting.

By strict geometric definitions, a sphere is *not* a three-dimensional SOLID.

Instead it is a curved, two-dimensional plane in three-dimensional space; the solid is called a *ball*. In other words, the difference between the surface of the Earth, and the Earth.

This sparked such lively debate last time, I'm surprised no one has brought it up.

Adorable puzzle! Best Monday in ages. 

Oh, and missed you Sam! Lovely to have your eloquent enthusiasm back with us.
yummy!  make Friday Saturday this good but tougher and Sunday stop catering to beginners!

With all the BUMBLEBEE chatter today, I thought I would share my one relevant experience. 

I was tooling down an Oregon road in my old Dodge hippie van, probably humming a Grateful Dead tune, windows open, tie-dyed curtains flapping, as I enjoyed a lovely day. 

THWACK! Something blown into the van had struck the pillar behind my left shoulder, recoiled forward and dropped down As it rebounded, I caught a glimpse of it -- I saw the yellow and said to myself, "self, that looks like a bee! Better make sure it didn't land on me." 

So  quickly assessed my lap, legs, etc. and not seeing a bee, I  didn't pull over. 

A few seconds later, in the general vicinity of my navel.... 

STING!!!

I swept it off me, pulled over, got out, and took a look. 

BUMBLEBEE. 

It didn't really hurt much - I probably knocked it away before it had a chance to pump much venom. And their stingers aren't barbed, so my hand brushed it away, removing the stinger, almost immediately. 

The stunned lady was lying there on the floor of the van, slowly waking. I watched it for a minute or two, until it started vibrating its wings, and then swept it outside, presumably to go on its merry BUMBLEBEE way. 

That is when I learned that the idea that BUMBLEBEEs don't sting was a myth, and I have never forgotten the lesson. But they are generally docile, so please don't fear them -- watch them, instead. They are fascinating creatures.

One more late puzzle find. It had dawned on me that.. SUNMONTUEWEDTHUFRISAT is.. 21 letters! And, yep it appeared in one puzzle, but... ... it was a Thursday from October 10, 2013 by Jeffrey Wechsler. It was a seven square rebus across the middle of the puzzle. Some crossing down answers: SUNyatsen leMON easyvirTUE areWEDone Here's that link: ] https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/10/2013&g=36&d=A ...

Fasten, tie, unite, bond...

CONNECT FOUR
Bumblebees Don‚Äôt Sting! Please stop spreading misinformation

Brood, flock, gaggle, herd, swarm, throng


SIX PACK

Cheadle, Henley, McLean, Lemon, Newcombe, Omar, Rickles, Shula, Toliver, Quixote


TENDONS

Or Dick for Richard?  Or Bob for Robert? Or Ned for Edward?

I nEVER before IF EVER ...

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

I caught on at JACKSON FIVE and was able to get all of the revealers with no crosses, a pleasant surprise.

It did take me a minute to figure out I FEVER.
Who cares whether or not they sting. If it fits, I will submit! üêù

At this point Yoko ONO isn‚Äôt a crossword answer ‚Äî she‚Äôs a long-term tenant. NYT Crossword, please evict her. There must be a federal limit for how many times one name can legally appear in 15√ó15 grids!

Bumblebee is a terrible answer. 
They can sting but they don‚Äôt often enough to suggest that it is an everyday fact or part of their existence. In fact, if they do, they die. 

It‚Äôs equivalent to having ‚Äúhumans‚Äù as the answer to Species that hops.

I am really surprised at the number of people who think/thought bumblebees don't sting.  How did that thought come about?

That's like being told some random dog doesn't bite.  I mean, he got teeth, don't he?

Why would a bumblebee have stingers if they don't sting?

N.B.  I am a big fan of Hymenoptera, and would never hurt one intentionally.
That was a perfect Monday puzzle.

What a terrific Monday puzzle. Busy day for me so I just finished it. Loved the whimsical theme. There are many many kinds of bees and they don‚Äôt all sting, of course. Thanks for the fun, Rena Cohen. üêùüêù

@Andrzej
Even ignoring the current political situation, US citizens are required to report all income made worldwide, as well as bank accounts holding more than the equivalent of US$10,000, to the Internal Revenue Service, regardless of where they reside. Actual US income tax liability only kicks in above a fairly generous threshold (and payroll tax‚Äîessentially, pensions‚Äîliability depends on binational agreements), but at the very least it would mean tedious annual paperwork. Given the power of a Schengen Area passport, it would be useful only if you had actual plans to visit or do business in the US extensively.

@K Deregibus - Yes, they do. See my story posted 45 minutes before this.

@K Deregibus Tell that to my 10 year old self who had a bumble bee stinger embedded in her underarm.  Unseen, it got infected and filled with green pus, and boy, did it ever hurt.  My father had enough of my crying one night and, under the glow of the back porch light, took his two thumbnails and PUSHED.   So, yes, they do indeed sting. They lose their stinger, just like honeybees.  Wasps, on the other hand, retain their stinger, and inject, inject, inject.  Either way, YOWCH.
